text: [Music]
well my first exposure to Jefferson was
when I was in the third grade I read a
biography of Jefferson a child's
biography of Jefferson and it was a
series part of a series you know Dolly
Madison George Washington Carver that
kind of thing that's sort of teach early
Civics lessons to a young kid
well uh sure and you know in terms of
where he was born and all those kinds of
things it had along with it um a story
about an enslave boy who was supposed to
be Jefferson same age and there was this
sort of contrast between Jefferson the
bright and energetic curious person and
the enslave boy he was kind of lazy and
playful you know he wanted to go fish
and do things while Jefferson know
wanted to get back to his books so it
wasn't an accurate portrayal to me I saw
this as sort of sending a message here
about the essential n nature of
Jefferson but also the essential nature
of of black people um because of all the
things you know you could have told a
story about a boy who uh the tragedy of
the fact that he didn't get to go to the
school but it was all uh it was very
opposites they were presented as
opposites black and white Jefferson and
this enslaved person so it you know it
told an accurate story in terms of the
sort of reference points of Jefferson's
life when he was born born and so forth
but not really the nature of southern
slave Society or black people really
